title.value: Score-based Enhanced Sampling for Protein Molecular Dynamics
title.justification: Extracted directly from the title of the paper
title.quote: Score-based Enhanced Sampling for Protein Molecular Dynamics

extractions.description: This paper proposes leveraging score-based generative models (SGMs) trained on large-scale general protein structures to perform protein conformational sampling. The proposed approach, named Score-based Enhanced Sampling (SENS), aims to complement traditional Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations by overcoming high-energy barriers in MD force fields. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of SENS on several benchmark systems by comparing the results with long MD trajectories and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed approach on several benchmark systems.
type.quote: Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark systems by comparing the results with long MD trajectories and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.

name.justification: The paper primarily focuses on protein conformational sampling and its dynamics using generative models.
name.quote: The dynamic nature of proteins is crucial for determining their biological functions and properties, and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations stand as a predominant tool to study such phenomena.

name.justification: The paper proposes using score-based generative models for protein conformational sampling.
name.quote: Inspired by tempering-based enhanced sampling methods (Marinari & Parisi, 1992), we leverage the score-based generative models (SGMs) (Ho et al., 2020; Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2015; Song et al., 2020) and present the Score-based ENhanced Sampling (SENS), a score-based framework for protein conformational sampling.

name.justification: The study aims to enhance traditional molecular dynamics simulations by addressing the high-energy barriers faced during MD simulations.
name.quote: A significant challenge encountered by MD simulations is the high energy-barriers, which forbid transitions within a limited number of simulation steps.

name.justification: SENS is the primary model proposed and examined in the paper.
name.quote: we leverage the score-based generative models (SGMs) (Ho et al., 2020; Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2015; Song et al., 2020) and present the Score-based ENhanced Sampling (SENS), a score-based framework for protein conformational sampling.

is_contributed.justification: The paper introduces and develops SENS as a novel approach for enhanced protein conformational sampling.
is_contributed.quote: we leverage the score-based generative models (SGMs) (Ho et al., 2020; Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2015; Song et al., 2020) and present the Score-based ENhanced Sampling (SENS), a score-based framework for protein conformational sampling.

is_executed.justification: SENS is executed and evaluated through experiments in the paper.
is_executed.quote: Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark systems by comparing the results with long MD trajectories and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.

is_compared.justification: SENS is compared with long MD simulations and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.
is_compared.quote: Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark systems by comparing the results with long MD trajectories and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.

referenced_paper_title.value: Score-based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Song et al., 2020 discusses score-based generative modeling, which forms the foundation for SENS.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we leverage the score-based generative models (SGMs) (Ho et al., 2020; Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2015; Song et al., 2020) and present the Score-based ENhanced Sampling (SENS), a score-based framework for protein conformational sampling.

name.justification: The Protein Data Bank (PDB) is the primary dataset used to train the Score-based Generative Models for protein structure data.
name.quote: SENS operates by dispersing the input conformation to its geometric neighborhood and then annealing back the perturbed conformations into respective equilibrium states with the learned score functions. This approach enables directly sampling of diverse conformation ensembles, thus effectively circumventing the high-energy barrier issue in traditional MD simulations. Moreover, SENS does not rely on any specific simulation data for training, and can be transferred to perform zero-shot conformational sampling by an amortized training. To assess the effectiveness of the SENS, we evaluate it on several benchmark systems, comparing the results with long MD simulations and state-of-the-art generative structure prediction models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Protein Data Bank (PDB) is properly cited in the paper.

name.justification: OpenMM is used for conducting short MD simulations in the experiments.
name.quote: To compare SENS with traditional molecular dynamics methods, we employ OpenMM (version 8.0) (Eastman et al., 2017) to conduct short MD simulations on our fast-folding protein benchmark systems as well as BPTI.

referenced_paper_title.value: OpenMM 7: Rapid development of high performance algorithms for molecular dynamics
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference paper for OpenMM is properly cited in the context of the paper.
